questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient was brought into the emergency department with a seizure that lasted 30 minutes without resolution. After securing airways & administering oxygen, which of the following pharmacologic agents is most appropriate to arrest the seizure?
questions.solution:
A short-acting benzodiazepine such as lorazepam is usually the best choice in the acute setting to arrest status epilepticus.

BZD In Status Epilepticus:

  • Lorazepam
  • Diazepam
  • Midazolam

Option A: Lignocaine is the most commonly used local anaesthetic agent. It is the drug of choice for the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias due to digitalis toxicity (ineffective in atrial arrhythmias) and ventricular arrhythmias after myocardial infarction.

Option C: Chlordiazepoxide is often combined with other drugs in psychosomatic disorders, and has been the commonest BZD used to cover alcohol withdrawal.

Option D: Triazolam A very potent short acting BZD who's peak effect occurs in < 1 hour; good for sleep induction.

Key Takeaway:

  • A short-acting benzodiazepine such as lorazepam is usually the best choice in the acute setting to arrest status epilepticus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came to the medicine department with a history of difficulty in onset of sleep and midnight insomnia. His physician has prescribed him Zaleplon for the same. For which of one of the following reasons Zaleplon differs from zolpidem?
questions.solution:
Zaleplon has a shorter elimination half-life.

Zaleplon, like zolpidem, has a more selective action than benzodiazepines. It has the advantage of a shorter half life and therefore is approved for patients who awaken in the middle of the night and cannot return to sleep.

Zaleplon

This is the shortest acting of the newer non-Benzodiazepines hypnotics that selectively act on a subset of BZD receptors containing the α1 subunit which appear to mediate the hypnotic action.

Key Takeaway:

  • Zaleplon decreases sleep latency without affecting total sleep time or sleep architecture (therefore useful in persons having difficulty falling asleep).

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery was brought to paediatric ICU with complaints of repeated attacks of flexion of neck over the trunk and jerks in the hands. EEG shows the presence of hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following anti-epileptic is the drug of choice for this patient for treatment of hypsarrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Infantile spasms are also called Salaam seizures Seen in West syndrome treated with ACTH. Vigabatrin is given if it is associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Option A, B & D: All other drugs are not indicated in infantile spasms.

Key Takeaway:

  • Infantile spasms is also called hypsarrhythmia in which ACTH is the Drug of choice

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of mild hepatic impairment brought to the medicine department with a seizure disorder. His physician has prescribed oxcarbazepine instead of carbamazepine. Which of the following adverse effects is more with oxcarbazepine as compared to carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Risk of hepatotoxicity is estimated to be lower with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine; but that of hyponatremia is more.

Side effects of Carbamazepine & Oxcarbazepine:

Drowsiness, diplopia, ataxia, GI disturbances, headache, dizziness, sedation, idiosyncratic reactions (skin rash, aplastic anemia), hepatotoxic, thrombocytopenia.

All These side effects are more with Carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

Key Takeaway:

  • Risk of Dilutional hyponatremia is more with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient named Raman with a history of epilepsy was on long term anticonvulsant therapy. After several years of treatment with anti-epileptic agent, he presented to ophthalmology department with complaints of decrease visual field and visual disturbances. On fundus examination, he was diagnosed of having retinal atrophy (as shown in the image below). Which of the following anti-epileptic drug is likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.
  • Vigabatrin is an irreversible inhibitor of GABA transaminase, thus increases GABAergic activity.
  • It is the DOC for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis (ACTH is DOC for all other cases).
  • It can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

Mnemonic:

  • Vigabatrin - Visual field defects

Option B: Ethosuximide causes gastrointestinal intolerance, tiredness, mood changes.

Option C: Phenobarbital Long term administration (as needed in epilepsy) may produce additional side effects like-behavioural abnormalities, diminution of intelligence, impairment of learning and memory, hyperactivity in children.

Option D: Levetiracetam can cause CNS adverse effects like irritability, aggression and lability of mood.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to psychiatry OPD with complaints of seizure disorder. She has a past history of brief episode of post traumatic seizure and wants to conceive. Which of the following antiepileptic drugs should be started as it is the least teratogenic drug during the pregnancy period?
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is the least teratogenic drug amongst all antiepileptics

Option A : Valproate causes Neural tube defects if used during pregnancy.

Option B : Phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome affecting craniofacial abnormalities and fingernail hypoplasia.

Option C: Carbamazepine causes Craniofacial anomalies and spina bifida if used during pregnancy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Levetiracetam is the least teratogenic drug amongst all antiepileptics. So preferred in pregnancy.

choices.text: Restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with recent onset primary generalised epilepsy was prescribed phenytoin sodium by his physician and later developed skin reaction due to phenytoin sodium (as given in the image below). Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin that warrants discontinuation of phenytoin.

ADRs of Phenytoin

Mnemonic

  • H - Hirsutism, Hypertrophy of gums
  • O - Osteomalacia
  • T - Teratogenicity [Fetal Hydantoin syndrome]
  • M - Megaloblastic Anemia [↓ Folate levels]
  • A - Arrhythmia [Only in overdose]
  • L - Lymph node enlargement
  • I - ↓ Insulin (avoided in Diabetes mellitus - Precipitates hyperglycemia)
  • K - ↓ Vitamin K levels
  • A - Ataxias, vertigo [cerebellar symptoms] [only at high dose]

Option A & D: Clonazepam and ethosuximide are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS.

Option B: Phenytoin is not started again after Initial Hypersensitivity reaction. So it's an incorrect option.

Option C: Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents Indicated for GTCS. Shifting to sodium valproate is the most appropriate course of action in this patient.

Key Takeaway:

  • Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of phenytoin. Shifting to Sodium valproate is done in GTCS Patients.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman came to the medicine department with a history of recently diagnosed simple partial seizures. She later started a therapy by her physician with lamotrigine. Which of the following serious adverse effects is most likely to occur during the therapy?
questions.solution:
• Lamotrigine causes a generalized erythematous skin rash in most patients taking the drug.
  • Several antiseizure drugs can cause skin hypersensitivity reactions, but lamotrigine is by far the drug most frequently involved.
  • The rash is usually mild, but severely affected patients may develop Steven-Johnson syndrome. The incidence of serious rash in pediatric patients (~0.8%) is higher than in the adult population (0.3%).

Other common adverse effects are:

  • Dizziness,
  • Ataxia,
  • Blurred or double vision,
  • Nausea & vomiting,
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

Option A : Phenytoin causes megaloblastic anemia due to decreased folate levels.

Option B : Levetiracetam causes Hallucinations rarely.

Option C : Sulphonamides, Procainamide, isoniazid etc drugs metabolised by Acetylation causes Lupoid syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

  • Lamotrigine causes a generalized erythematous skin rash in most patients taking the drug.

choices.text: Metabolism follows only zero order kinetics
Metabolized extensively by the CYP enzymes in the liver

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman came to the medicine department with a history of recently diagnosed Generalised tonic clonic seizures. She later started a therapy by her physician with Phenytoin. Which of the following statements about phenytoin is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Metabolism of phenytoin does not ONLY follow zero-order kinetics. Ethanol is the only drug that follows absolute zero-order kinetics from the beginning.

The kinetics of metabolism is capacity limited; changes from first order to zero order over the therapeutic range.

Phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations. As the concentration increases, the elimination changes to zero-order kinetics (pseudo-zero order).

The rate of elimination of phenytoin varies with the serum concentration. As a result small increments in dose produce disproportionately high plasma concentrations.

The t½ (12-24 hours at therapeutic levels), progressively increases (upto 60 hr) when plasma concentration rises above 10 μg/ml because metabolizing enzymes get saturated. So Monitoring of plasma concentration is very helpful in adjusting dosage.

Option A: About 80-90% of phenytoin is bound to plasma proteins-mainly albumin.

Option C: The half-life (12-24 hours) disproportionately increases (up to 60 hours) when concentrations exceed 10 mcg/mL and therefore phenytoin needs therapeutic drug monitoring.

Option D: Phenytoin is metabolized by the CYP enzymes in the liver which involves hydroxylation and subsequent glucuronide conjugation.

Key Takeaway:

  • Metabolism of phenytoin is capacity limited; changes from first order to zero order over the therapeutic range with Increasing dose.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is testing new potential inhalational anaesthetics in laboratory animals. Some pharmacological parameters of each drug are recorded in the table below. Based on the given data below which of the following drugs has the highest potency? [MAC=minimum alveolar concentration]
questions.solution:
Minimal alveolar concentration (MAC):

  • It is the lowest concentration of the anaesthetic in the pulmonary alveoli needed to produce immobility in response to a painful stimulus (surgical incision) in 50% individuals.
  • It is accepted as a valid measure of potency of inhalational GAs, because it remains fairly constant for most young adults. The lower the MAC, the higher the potency.
  • The speed of induction is a pharmacokinetic parameter and can tell us nothing about the potency of a drug (a pharmacodynamic parameter).
  • The MAC of a number of GAs shows excellent correlation with their oil/gas partition coefficient. However, this only reflects capacity of the anaesthetic to enter into CNS and attain sufficient concentration in the neuronal membrane.

Option A , B & C:

With Increasing MAC, Potency Decreases. So the Potency sequence is : Drug S >> Drug P > Drug Q > Drug R.

Key Takeaway:

  • The lower the Minimal alveolar concentration (MAC), higher the potency. Methoxyflurane having lowest MAC is Most Potent.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient visits an otolaryngologist with complaints of recurrent sinusitis. The surgeon decides to perform sinus surgery to debride the scarred sinus tissue. During the procedure, the surgeon elects to use an agent that has good local anesthesia as well as vasoconstrictive properties. Which of the following agents is the most suitably surgeon has used?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is ideal for such surgery because of its topical activity; it does not require the addition of epinephrine, as it has intrinsic vasoconstrictive activity that aids in hemostasis.

  • All LAs are vasodilators except cocaine which is a vasoconstrictor. Therefore, all LAs decrease BP except cocaine (increases).
  • Cocaine should NEVER be given by intravenous route or with adrenaline.
  • Cocaine is the only ester which is not metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. It is metabolized in the liver.

Cocaine blocks uptake of NA and Adr into adrenergic nerve endings

Results in higher concentration of the transmitter around the receptors

↓

Sympathomimetic effect,

↓

Potentiation of directly acting sympathomimetics and suppression of indirectly acting sympathomimetics

↓

Local vasoconstriction, tachycardia, rise in BP and mydriasis

Option B & C: Similar to cocaine, both procaine and tetracaine are ester-type compounds but without Vasoconstriction properties; however, procaine is not topically active and tetracaine is used primarily for spinal anesthesia and ophthalmologic procedures.

Option D: Lidocaine is an amide anesthetic preferred for infiltrative blocks and epidural anesthesia without Vasoconstriction properties.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine has topical LA activity & has intrinsic vasoconstrictive activity that aids in hemostasis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient visits his dentist for a routine checkup. He finds that his wisdom teeth are severely impacted and need to be removed. The oral surgeon to whom he is referred plans on using an agent that has good analgesic and sedative properties but does not cause skeletal muscle relaxation. Which agent has these ideal properties?
questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide is an anesthetic gas that has good analgesic and sedative properties without the skeletal muscle-relaxing effects.

It can be used along with other inhaled agents decreasing their concentrations and thus their side effects.

Option A: Enflurane produces anesthesia, hypnosis, and muscle relaxation, as do the others, and is very pungent.

Option C: Thiopental is a barbiturate that is too short acting for this application. It's used intravenously in General Anesthesia Induction.

Option D: Halothane has a pleasant odor and produces a smooth and relatively rapid induction, but decreases cardiac output and can result in an unpredictable hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaway:

  • Nitrous oxide is an anesthetic gas that has good analgesic and sedative properties without the skeletal muscle-relaxing effects.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient came to the medicine department with complaints of chronic gastritis which are unresolved. His physician has prescribed him a local anaesthetic agent for the same. Which of the following local anaesthetic is commonly used symptomatic relief of gastritis?
questions.solution:
Oxethazaine is a potent local anesthetic with a unique property of ionizing to a very small extent even at low pH values.

Therefore, it is effective in anesthetizing gastric mucosa despite acidity of the medium and used for symptomatic relief of gastritis.

Oxethazaine is swallowed along with antacids it affords symptomatic relief in following conditions

  • Gastritis,
  • Drug induced gastric irritation,
  • Gastroesophageal reflux and
  • Heartburn of pregnancy.

Side effects: (Occurs at high dose)

  • Dizziness
  • Drowsiness

Option A, B & D: All other agents are not ionised at Low pH and have no role in management of gastritis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Oxethazaine is effective in anesthetizing gastric mucosa and used for symptomatic relief of gastritis due to unique property of acting at low pH.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man diagnosed with inguinal hernia was prepared for surgery. Shortly after the initiation of general anaesthesia with halothane and succinylcholine, the patient developed muscle rigidity, tachycardia, fluctuating blood pressure, profuse diaphoresis, and high fever (104.2°F). The anaesthesia was discontinued and a drug was administered by rapid intravenous push. Which of the following was most likely the mechanism of action of the administered drug?
questions.solution:
• The clinical picture of the patient suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia.
  • A rare but potentially life-threatening disorder that can be triggered by a variety of stimuli including Administration of certain Inhaled anaesthetics (mainly halothane) and Neuromuscular blocking agents (mainly succinylcholine)

The disorder is related to a hereditary impairment in the ability of the sarcoplasmic reticulum to sequester calcium

↓

Therefore, a prolonged release of calcium occurs

↓

Triggering event through sarcoplasmic calcium channels

↓

This causes massive muscle contraction, hyperthermia, and lactic acidosis

Dantrolene is a drug of choice in this disorder because it blocks Ca2+ channels in the skeletal muscle sarcoplasmic reticulum,

↓

Thus preventing the massive release of calcium.

Dantrolene:

Key Takeaway:

  • Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts via Blockade of Ca2+ channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman was admitted to the day surgery center for strabismus surgery. This surgery is considered highly emetogenic due to a stimulation of the vomiting center during the operative manipulation of extraocular muscles. Which of the following anaesthetics would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic with an onset and duration of anaesthesia similar to that of thiopental.

It is the only anaesthetic with antiemetic action, so it is the preferred drug in patients at high risk of nausea and vomiting, as in this case.

Option A, B & C: All other agents given here promote vomiting hence should not be used here.

Key Takeaway:

  • Propofol is the only Intravenous induction anaesthetic with antiemetic action.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman underwent hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. The general anaesthesia protocol included sodium thiopental, isoflurane, nitrous oxide, and tubocurarine. The anaesthesiologist also administered another drug to counteract tubocurarine-induced hypotension. Which of the following classes did this drug most likely belong?
questions.solution:
Tubocurarine-induced hypotension is primarily due to histamine release, and premedication with an antihistamine drug is often used to attenuate this adverse effect.

d-Tubocurarine produces significant fall in BP.

This is due to-

  • Ganglionic blockade
  • Histamine release and
  • Reduced venous return-a result of paralysis of limb and respiratory muscles.

Option A, B & C: d-Tubocurarine induced hypotension is primarily due to histamine release. So Beta 1 Agonist, Muscarinic agonist and Cholinesterase inhibitors are Wrong Options.

Key Takeaway:

  • d-Tubocurarine induced hypotension is primarily due to histamine release so Treated with Antihistamines.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient was admitted for surgery. He had a history of having mild hepatic and renal impairment. Which of the following is a muscle relaxant of choice in a patient with elevated SGPT, SGPT and serum creatinine of 7.5 mg/dl with creatinine clearance of <45 ml/min?
questions.solution:
• Atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman's elimination.
  • It means it neither requires liver for metabolism, nor kidney for excretion. Its molecules spontaneously rearrange to make it inactive.
  • Thus it is the safest muscle relaxant in a patient with liver and kidney disease.

Option A: Vecuronium undergoes both Hepatic metabolic and Renal Elimination. So Not Preferred in Liver and Renal Impairment.

Option B: Pancuronium undergoes renal elimination. So not preferred in Renal Impairment.

Option C: Pipecuronium undergoes both Hepatic metabolic and Renal Elimination. So Not Preferred in Liver and Renal Impairment.

Key Takeaway:

  • Atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman's elimination, Its molecules spontaneously rearrange to make it inactive. so it neither requires liver for metabolism, nor kidney for excretion.
